headline: CNN Newsroom
subHeadline: Murdaugh Testifies In His Murder Trial About Financial Issues At Work; Murdaugh: "I Did" Steal Client Funds From Law Firm; Murdaugh Admits Asking Man To Shoot Him To Death. Aired 3-3:30p ET

utterances.speaker: ALEX MURDAUGH, MURDER DEFENDANT
utterances.sentences: Because a secretary other than mine, apparently other than mine was going to be the person who was going to put those - that financial information into the final document and that's the document that Mark Ball talked about that he found on my desk whenever it was that he found it.So that was what was going to be, if necessary, what was going to be used Thursday.

utterances.speaker: JIM GRIFFIN, DEFENSE ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Juries heard about testimony of you stealing client funds. Did you do that?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Did you steal or divert that (inaudible) fee away from the law firm?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: How did you get in such a financial predicament that led you to steal money that wasn't yours?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not quite sure how I let myself get where I got. But it came from - I battled that addiction for so many years, I was spending so much money on pills. I got in the spot I couldn't ...

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Now, what type of addiction are you referring to?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: My addiction is to opiate painkillers ...

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And when did you ...

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: ... specifically oxycodone, OxyContin.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And when did you first become dependent or addicted to opioids?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Oxycodone or opiates in general?

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Opiates in general.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'm not quite sure the exact date but I can give you a timeframe. I hurt my knee really bad playing football in college and I had a knee surgery, and the medical science at the time was such that the surgery didn't work bottom line, so it just didn't last.So within a couple of years of that, I started having a lot of knee troubles. And ultimately, I had to have a couple of surgeries. But this - the last surgery I had was, I think, around 2002 or four and I think it was around four, so I would have started taking hydrocodone a couple of years before that. And I took hydrocodone got addicted to that very quickly. I continued taking that for a long time, I would - I force myself after that we myself off of it, lean myself off of it, I go back to it. I just - I battled that for a long time. And after a while I was taking so much of that I moved on to oxycodone. And I'm guessing that was around 2000, that transition was around 2008, '09, something like that. And, of course, it just escalates it escalates, it escalates and ...

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Did you receive treatment or go to detox on occasion?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: How many times?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: That I went to detox or that I detoxed?

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Well, let's start with going to a detox facility.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I've been to a detox facility three times.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And when was the first time?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: December of 2017.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Okay. And before December 2017, had you tried to detox at home?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I tried to detox everywhere I could.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: When you ...

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Maggie would help me - go ahead.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. When you went in to - was it inpatient facility?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: The detox is - the formal detoxes that I went to?

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, in December 2017.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, it was inpatient. All three former detoxes that I've done had been at the same facility called Sunrise Detox in Atlanta, Georgia. It's a very good facility.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And juries heard an audio tape of a telephone conference with SLED agents, was that where you were during that meeting with Mr. Harpootlian?

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: The first time you went to the detox in Atlanta, how long of a stay is that? Did you stay?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Seven days is the opiate detox program.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And is there a difference between detox and rehab?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: What's the difference?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Detox is the act of getting the drugs out of your system. Getting to the point where, okay, there is no longer a physical dependency, right, and that's a big difference than the rest of the dependency. But the physical dependency is supposed to be gone after seven days.So in other words, the - I mean, there are so many things - opiate withdrawal is - I mean, it's hard. But supposedly, at the end of seven days, you don't have those physical symptoms, like - I don't want to be too graphic - but you're sick, you throw up. You have terrible diarrhea. You sweat like you're running a marathon. You can't hold your legs still. You can't lay down now, like, what I'm talking about the legs moving, that goes away after about 24 hours. So after about 24 hours, you can lay down again and maybe sleep some, but you sweat, you throw up. I mean, you just have - there's so many issues, but after seven days, those are supposed to be over. That's what detox is, the detoxification of your body.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And what's rehab?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Rehab is the period that you go to learn how to stay off. You're supposedly off after detox, rehab is where you get help staying off.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And before September 2021, had you ever gone to that second stage of rehab?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: So in June - excuse me - December 2017, how long did it take you to relapse once you got home from detox?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Not long at all. I mean, you're still going through - this physical dependency is gone, you still have - I mean, you're still so sick. I mean, you just ...

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Is that something you've been battling for quite some time?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: As long as I can remember.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: How long you've been drug free opioid free? MURDAUGH

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: I want to ask you questions about Labor Day weekend 2021.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Okay.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Do you remember being confronted by your law firm?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Sure, I did.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And what were you confronted about?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Stealing money.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And did you admit your misconduct to your law partners?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Well, to one of my law partners and one of my - and my brother and my law partner, Danny and Randy, yes. I mean ...

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Did ...

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: ... admit it, admitted them.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And they learned about fake Forge account. Did you admit the fake Forge account?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And did you tell them about your opioid struggles, opioid addiction?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I told them about my addiction. Yes, sir.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: To your knowledge, are any of your law partners aware of your addiction?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Not just to my knowledge, I'm certain that they were not aware of my addiction.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: How would you characterize your opioid use or addiction, severe? Moderate?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Then or now?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, I don't know how would I characterize it then. After going to rehab and learning more of the things I've learned, really talking to addicts about experiences, I mean I'll - I will tell you that my addiction was extremely, extremely bad.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: How were you able to function or were you able to function?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes, I was able to function.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: You're able to practice law?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And were you successful practicing law while you were addicted to opioids?

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: After you were confronted on Labor Day weekend 2021, did you resign or were you forced to resign from a law firm?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And then on Saturday, September the 4th, do you remember what happened that day?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Saturday, September 4th? Yes, sir. I remember.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And what happened?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It started when I woke up.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFN
utterances.sentences: Well, let's start after you met with Chris Wilson, did you meet with Chris Wilson?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I met with Chris Wilson at my mom's and dad's house in Alameda.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And did you lay it out for Chris Wilson your opioid addiction and your misconduct?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I definitely laid out my addiction, I definitely gave him some details about monies that I had taken. I didn't give him - we didn't go into all the details about all of it, but I certainly was very candid with him about the things that involved him.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Had you already just contacted the detox facility, before you met with Chris Wilson on the fourth?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I believe that we had already - at that point, I believe that we had already spoken to the guy that I knew from sunrise and made arrangements for me to go there on Monday.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Okay. And ...

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I know we had arrangements for me to go there on Monday and I - I'm - so we had to have had it by then, because I went to the hospital shortly after that, so yes.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And did you reach out to Blanca (ph) to get your insurance information?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And for what purpose?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Because I was going to use my insurance at detox and rehab to help pay for it.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Okay. And what would - what was your immediate plans after - I mean, for the day after you met with Chris Wilson, did you have plans to do anything - have any other meetings on that Saturday?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I wanted to go and meet with Cory Fleming who was another lawyer who was affected by things I did.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And did you ...

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: And a good friend.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Did you go meet with Cory Fleming?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: What did you do instead?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I'd given my - when I gave my pills to my brother Randy and Danny - I think I gave them to Randy. But I'd taken - I took a lot of pills, because I knew I won't going to be taking any more. So Randy had pills. I had to get some from him the night before, but only got a small amount. I could tell - I wasn't taking anything near like what I had been taking, so I knew it was coming. And I called someone to bring me more pills and before - I believe before I met with Chris Wilson.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And did you meet this - did the person you call bring you more pills?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I don't know if he brought me more pills or not because by the time I met with him after meeting with Chris and after the starting of the withdrawals, I changed my plan.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And what was the change and plans?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Not to get pills from him anymore and instead I asked him to shoot me.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Did you ask him to shoot you as a sympathy ploy or did you want to die?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: As a sympathy ploy?

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, sir. Why did you asked him to shoot you? What was the end goal in your - that you wanted to accomplish?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I meant for him to shoot me so I'd be gone.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Eddie Smith.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And did he in fact shoot you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: He did.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And where was that located - not your gunshot, but where were shot in Hampton and Colleton County, where were you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: It's Hampton County. It's right on the border of Salkehatchie Road that runs right along the Salkehatchie River.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And why did you want to be gone?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I mean, I knew all this was coming to a head. I knew how humiliating it was going to be for my son. I mean, I've been through so much at the time and the bad place that I was. It seemed like a better thing to do. I don't think that way now, thankfully, but I did at the time.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Did you have life insurance on you?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. I had a lot of life insurance.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: And who was the beneficiary?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Maggie was the beneficiary.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: How much life insurance did you have?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I had $12 million. I had a $4 million policy and a 12 - and an $8 million policy, a total of 12.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Did you ever have any life insurance on Maggie?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, never.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Did you ever have any life insurance on Paul?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Alex, will you tell the story about Maggie and your relationship with her.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Alex, would you ...

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: A special person.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Would you ever do anything to harm Maggie?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: I would never hurt Maggie, ever.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Will you tell the jury about Paul, please, and your relationship with him.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Alex ...

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: He's the most special boy.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: ... do you love Paul?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: God I love him like no other, he and Buster.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Do you love Maggie?

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: More than anything. I love Maggie from the first time we went out. GRIFFIN

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: No, I did not kill Maggie. I did not kill Paul. I would never hurt Maggie and I would never hurt Paul, ever, under any circumstances.

utterances.speaker: GRIFFIN
utterances.sentences: Thank you. (Inaudible) answer any questions (inaudible) may ask.

utterances.speaker: MURDAUGH
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ladies and gentlemen, we'll take a --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Excuse me.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We'll take a 10 minute recess. Please do not discuss the case.

utterances.speaker: BIANNA GOLODRYGA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: More bombshell testimony, about 45 minutes of testimony there from Alex Murdaugh testifying there at Walterboro, South Carolina courtroom on his murder trial.Let's bring in Jean Casarez and Dave Aronberg, state attorney for Palm Beach County, Florida. Jean, to you first. When I said bombshell, I mean bombshell and the fact that he's admitted to stealing money from his firm.
